questions.question_text:
An administrator needs additional capacity on a vSAN cluster. Each host currently has only one disk group.
Which two approaches can be used to expand storage capacity in this situation? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Increase the number of cache disks in the existing disk group.
choices.C: Increase the number of capacity disks in the existing disk group.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A disk group can only have one cache disk, and the cache does not contribute to the capacity of the vSAN (No C)
Deduplication and compression are mechanisms to optimize space, disabling it results in the opposite of what is requested (No D and E).

questions.question_text: Which component is upgraded when using the SDDC Manager management domain upgrade workflow in VMware Cloud Foundation?

comments.content: VMware NSX-T Manager nodes ( we assume for MGMT WLD ) this seems to be best answer

As far as I'm aware, the terminology for VCF domains is kinda tricky, just like in NSX where ESXi hosts and Edge Nodes are generalized as 'Transport Nodes', VCF generalizes any domain (either Management or VI Workload) as 'Workload Domain'.

Refer to this link: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/5.0/vcf-lifecycle/GUID-1670629D-ABAC-4349-9C8F-CECCF370DB5E.html

Search for subtitle "Precheck Update - Versions Prior to SDDC Manager 5.0" in the "Procedure" section it shows a screenshot of the SDDC Manager UI and states: "On the Workload Domains page, click the workload domain where you want to run the precheck.".

Thus, I would say option A could also be an answer. 

Not saying option C is not correct, but option A seems more fit in my opinion.

- YoMeroElPlomero

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Management domain upgrade does not upgrade VI Workload domain components.
